reg:regulation.reg:title: Sensitive Streams Designation and Licensing Regulation

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this regulation, Act means the Fish Protection Act.
This regulation applies to an application for a licence, an approval or an amendment to a licence or an approval, in respect of a sensitive stream.
The streams listed in the Schedule are designated as sensitive streams under section 6 (2) of the Act.

If an applicant relies on a report of an expert or other form of evidence prepared by an expert and submitted with or in support of the application, the comptroller or regional water manager must be satisfied that the expert is qualified to provide that evidence.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Powers to require additional information for purposes of application
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of considering an application, the comptroller or regional water manager may, at any time, require the applicant to provide further relevant information including, but not limited to, any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fish inventory;
flow or runoff analysis, including additional flow measurements for correlation of data;
seasonal distribution of water demand, including irrigation;
habitat assessment at the point of diversion and in the area of potential impact;
design of proposed works including diversion structure, balancing and storage reservoirs;
where appropriate, any specific water conservation measures that the applicant will utilize to minimize use of water;
the removal of material from the stream or stream channel in connection with the works;
the protection of natural materials and vegetation that contribute to habitat or stream channel stability;
the addition of substance, sediment, debris or other material to the stream or stream channel in connection with the works;
the restoration of the work site after the works have been completed.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Onus on applicant to comply with all other relevant enactments
bcl:section.bcl:text: In respect of an application for a water licence, approval or amendment to a licence or an approval, it is the responsibility of the applicant to ensure compliance with all other relevant federal, provincial or municipal enactments.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In regard to an application for a water licence, approval or amendment to a licence or an approval, an applicant must provide information to the comptroller or regional water manager on mitigation strategies during project planning, design, construction and operation, which may include but are not limited to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the timing of any proposed work;
practices to be undertaken to ensure stream bank and channel stability;
practices that provide for satisfactory fish migration;
practices that provide that fish are not injured or their migration hindered by structures, pumping devices or construction activities;
practices and procedures to maintain water quality;
measures to restore the stream channel and banks to their natural state;
metering of water use;
water conservation measures.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For subsection (1) (f), natural state means as close as possible to the state that exists before the work is to begin as proposed by the application.
The comptroller or regional water manager may make it a condition of a licence, approval or amendment to a licence or an approval that the licensee provide on site monitoring of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the construction of the works authorized under the licence, approval or amendment to the licence or approval, and
mitigation measures to ensure that they are performed as required under the licence, approval or amendment to the licence or approval.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Any on site monitoring required under this regulation must be carried out by a person whose qualifications are acceptable to the comptroller or regional water manager.
Post construction monitoring may be discontinued only if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the on site monitor certifies in writing that all works have been completed and are functioning as required in the mitigation plan, or
the applicant is relieved of the monitoring requirement by the comptroller or regional water manager.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, in kind compensation means fish habitat that is provided in place of or instead of fish habitat that would suffer a significant adverse impact under the proposal.
If an applicant proposes to provide in kind compensation for fish habitat that would suffer a significant adverse impact under the proposed use, the compensation proposal

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be for the fish population whose sustainability is at risk,
must provide for the same habitat type as that of the fish population being displaced, and
must be in equal proportion to or greater than the fish habitat that will be lost.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A proposal for in kind compensation for fish habitat must make full compensation for the significant adverse impact on the fish habitat by providing for in kind compensation in the following locations and in the following order of priority:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the same location where the projected habitat impact will occur;
within the same stream system;
within the same watershed;
within another area immediately adjacent to the same watershed having similar physiography and macroclimate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the in kind compensation at the first applicable location listed in subsection (3) is insufficient to fully compensate for the significant adverse impact on the fish habitat, the proposal must provide for the remainder of the compensation to be satisfied at the next applicable location in the list.
The applicant will be responsible for monitoring and maintenance of the in kind compensation for fish habitat until one of the following occurs:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the comptroller or regional water manager is satisfied that the objectives of the compensation plan are met;
the comptroller or regional water manager directs that the applicant is no longer responsible for monitoring and maintenance of the in kind compensation for fish habitat.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (9), (10) and (11), if in kind compensation cannot be achieved as provided in subsections (2) to (4), the comptroller or regional water manager may approve financial compensation for the habitat that will suffer a significant adverse impact.

If financial compensation is approved by the comptroller or regional water manager, the applicant must employ a person whose qualifications are acceptable to the comptroller or regional water manager to determine the cost of recreating the habitat that will suffer a significant adverse impact, including the cost of developing and monitoring any plan.

In considering whether to accept financial or in kind compensation, the comptroller or the regional water manager must consider whether the approval of the federal Department of Fisheries and Oceans has been obtained in respect of that compensation.

The comptroller or regional manager must not accept compensation under section 6 of the Act in relation to a fish population if the fish population whose sustainability is at risk is a species of fish designated under the Wildlife Act as a threatened or endangered species.
The comptroller or regional manager may refuse to accept compensation under section 6 of the Act in relation to a fish population if the fish population whose sustainability is at risk is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: of regional significance, or
genetically or geographically distinct.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The comptroller or regional manager must not accept compensation under section 6 of the Act if the impact on fish habitat of implementing the proposal would critically reduce the sustainability of the fish population.
